bibl.title: Letter fragment from Merritte W. Ireland to Albert E. Truby, September 6, 1941

div1.p: Ireland compliments Truby on his manuscript about his experiences with the yellow fever commission.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Merritte W. Ireland to Albert E. Truby, September 6, 1941
div1.opener:
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
1870 Wyoming Avenue,
Washington, D. C.
September 6, 1941
eral A. E. Truby, U. S. A.,
5 Laurel Street,
n Francisco, Calif.
y dear Truby:
div1.p:
Tuesday evening Kean telephoned to me that he
finally had your manuscript and had completed read-
ing it the first time. I went over after dinner to
get it and when I started to read it I could not put
it down. I never read a novel in my life (not even
Wyatt Earp) that held my attention as that did and I
completed 75 pages before going to bed and completed
the rest of it the next day. It is really remarkable,
Truby, and I am so glad that you have committed your
experience in Cuba and with the yellow fever commission
to paper. It is a real contribution to medicine.
